Paragraph 1.1.1.p30: "– При чём тут ещё состояние невесомости? – буркнул профессор." Character: "профессор" (professor). Is that a person? It's a title; could be generic, but it's a person speaking. Paragraph 1.1.1.p31: mentions "Знайка". That's a character. Also narrator? So include Znaika (Знайка). Gender? Likely male (in Russian children literature Znaika is a boy). But we must base on evidence; text doesn't specify gender. Might infer male? Possibly safe to "unknown". But we could say "male" if external knowledge, but rule says use evidence only. No gender indicated. So "unknown".

Also "профессор" appears again? Not in this paragraph.

Paragraph 1.1.1.p32: mentions "Звёздочкин". That's a character. Gender unknown; text says "сердито проворчал Звёздочкин". Could be male? Not specified. So unknown.

Thus we have three characters: профессор, Знайка, Звёздочкин.

For each, canonicalName normalized nominative: "профессор", "Знайка", "Звёздочкин". Aliases: any inflected forms appear: "профессор" (the word only). No other forms. "Знайка" appears only as that. "Звёздочкин" appears as that; earlier phrase "Звёздочкин" only; maybe "профессор" appears in "буркнул профессор". That's same. No separate aliases.

Description: 1-3 sentences grounded.

For professor: "Буркнул профессор, задавая вопрос о состоянии невесомости." That's within paragraph 1.
